title: String Formatting and f-strings
description: Predict output, run code, and investigate f-strings for variable insertion and handling quotes.

sections.title: Introduction: Formatting Strings
sections.content: Printing messages that include variable values is common. Python's f-strings provide a powerful way to do this. In this section, you'll predict the output of specific lines before running the code to see if you're correct.

sections.title: Predict, Run, Investigate: Print Statements
sections.introduction: Below is Python code that attempts to print greetings using different methods. Focus on the code, predict the output for the specified line, then run it to check.

examples.code:
# We'll use a fixed name for prediction
name = "Alex"

print(f"Hello {name}it's nice to meet you!") # Line 1
print("Hello {name} it's nice to meet you!") # Line 2
print(f"Hello {name} it's nice to meet you!") # Line 3
print(f"Hello name it's nice to meet you!") # Line 4
examples.predictPrompt: Look closely at Line 3 (`print(f"Hello {name} it's nice to meet you!")`). What exact text will this line output?
examples.expectedPrediction: Hello Alex it's nice to meet you!
examples.predictionTargetDescription: Exact output of the third print statement
examples.explanationPrompt: Your prediction didn't match the actual output from Line 3. Why did the code produce the output it did? Consider how the `f` prefix and curly braces `{}` affect the string.

sections.conclusion: Running the code reveals how different print statements behave. Only the f-string with `{name}` correctly substituted the variable. The other lines either missed the `f`, lacked braces, or had spacing issues. Understanding f-strings is key for clean output!

sections.title: Data Type Check
sections.content: When using `name = input("What is your name? ")`, what data type does the `input()` function *always* return for the `name` variable?

feedback.correct: Correct! The `input()` function always returns a string, even if the user types numbers.
feedback.incorrect: Remember that the `input()` function in Python always captures user input as a string.

sections.title: Why Double Quotes?
sections.content: In the code `print(f"Hello {name} it's nice to meet you!")`, why is using double quotes (`"`) useful for defining the f-string?
options: Python requires double quotes for f-strings.
It allows the single quote (apostrophe) in `it's` to be included without causing a syntax error.
Double quotes make the f-string process faster.
Variables can only be inserted into double-quoted strings.

feedback.correct: Correct! Using double quotes for the string allows single quotes (apostrophes) to be included within the string without prematurely ending it.
feedback.incorrect: Consider what happens if you try to define a string like `'it's'` using only single quotes. Python allows both, but choosing the outer quote type wisely helps manage quotes inside the string.

Your task is to write a single `print` statement using an f-string that greets the user (whose name is stored in the `name` variable) in this grammatically correct way.
